answers.author: David Evertsen
answers.text:
Hi Adam. 
Many municipalities I have worked with are also trying to reduce costs. You have several options:

Fire Department. Why isn't your Fire Department doing this? Most Fire Departments we have worked with - maintaining hydrants is included in their job descriptions and within the collective bargaining agreement terms. 

As a former CM, LDS member and former Boy Scout Commissioner, you have some additional options. 

Some use local LDS (Mormon) youth groups for service projects (they do it at no cost). 
Many Boy Scout troops will do it for free as part of someone's Eagle Scout Projects - depending on the number of hydrants you need done - you could really get quite a few done.  

Going back to the City Manager with $3,000 - $5,000 in cost savings could be a real 'atta-boy'. 
If you need help contacting some local troops or LDS youth groups in the area, I can give you a hand (no charge for my services) - just trying to help. 
David Evertsen, CEO
Municipal Solutions llc
devertsen@municipalsolutions.org
Mobile 623.207.1309

answers.author: Michael Van Milligen
answers.text:
Dubuque has  2,334  public fire hydrants that are being painted over several  years. The projected final expense for this project including the contractors cost and engineering costs of services in writing specifications, inspections and monitoring the project for ( paint thickness and lead base paint removal) compliance is $259,019. This equates to approximately $111 per hydrant.

author: Adam Lehmann
text:
Lake County, Illinois is conducting a cost analysis for painting fire hydrants and caps. I am curious about the cost for other counties/municipalities in the Midwest (similar climate/weather for the comparison). How much do you pay per hydrant?
Please contact me (Adam Lehmann) directly at alehmann@lakecountyil.gov or 847-377-2238.
title: Painting Fire Hydrants
